# NTM / MOTT Mycobacteria Other Than Tuberculosis

**Environmental organisms typically found in** (soil) **and** (water)

(Essay)

*   Natural water sources ✓
*   Drinking water distribution systems (biofilm formation)
*   Hot tubs and spas
    *   → community Hot tubs
    *   → Hot tub lung [Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis]
*   Acidic, brown-water swamps
*   Potting soils ✓
*   Metal removal fluid systems

Most human **pulmonary NTM disease** is caused by
*   **M. avium** ✓
*   **M. abscessus** ✓
*   **M. kansasii** and
*   **M. xenopi** ✓

---

<!-- Page 3 -->



# RUNYON CLASSIFICATION



## Slow growers : (6-8) weeks



### Pigment producers
*   **I. Photo chromogens** (Pigment only in presence of light) (MASK)
    *   M. Marinum
    *   M. Asiaticum
    *   M. Simiae
    *   M. Kansasii
    *   *(Handwritten note: wear MASK in sunlight)*

*   **II. Scotochromogens** (Pigment in light & dark)
    *   M. gordonae
    *   M. scrofulaceum



### Non pigment
*   **III. Non Photochromogens**
    *   M. avium
    *   M. ulcerans
    *   M. Xenopi
    *   *(Handwritten note: AUX cable. Coloured)*



## IV. Rapid growers (1 week)
*   M. fortuitum
*   M. abscessus
*   M. chelonae
*   *(Handwritten note: Fack fast)*

---

*   Buruli ulcer (M. ulcerans infection)
    *   *(Image: A deep, open ulcer on a limb)*
*   Swimming pool / Fish tank granuloma (M. Marinum)
*   Endoscope contamination: M. chelonae
*   Opportunistic infection (MAC)
*   HOT TUB LUNG => Mycobacterium avium
*   Lady Windermere syndrome => M. avium

# Risk Factors : Pulmonary NTM Infection

*   **Structural Lung Abnormalities**
    *   Bronchiectasis
    *   COPD
    *   Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (Lipid MΦ)
    *   Pneumoconiosis

*   **Genetic**
    *   cystic fibrosis
    *   α1-antitrypsin deficiency

*   **Others**
    *   Gastroesophageal reflux, esophageal dysmotility
    *   Older age
    *   Lower BMI
    *   Female sex
    *   Immunosuppression
    *   Scoliosis, pectus excavatum
    *   Mitral valve prolapse

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD, DNB, FIP, FACI, EDARM

<!-- Page 5 -->



# Transmission of NTM



## Likely routes of infection

*   Inhalation of NTM-laden aerosols or dust
*   Ingestion of soil or water
*   Contamination of hospital water supplies and medical equipment
*   Person-to-person transmission extremely rare, but some evidence of this in the CF community
*   Gastroesophageal reflux disease has been indicated as a mediator of NTM-LD

---

**Handwritten Notes:**

*   Inhalation of NTM-laden aerosols/dust
*   Ingestion of soil/water
*   Contamination of HPTL water/medical equipment
*   Person-to-person transmission
*   GERD
*   -> lung disease

<!-- Page 6 -->



# PATHOGENESIS

Abnormal airway clearance allows persistence of pulmonary NTMs that would otherwise normally be cleared
Once infection is established, pulmonary NTMs can persist within biofilms and macrophages, which may shield NTMs from antibiotic therapy
the natural history of disease is generally one of slowly progressive lung destruction over a course of years

# CLINICAL PRESENTATION & DIAGNOSTICS



## Clinical
*   cough, ✓ (Mimic TB)
*   sputum production, ✓
*   weight loss, ✓
*   haemoptysis, ✓
*   shortness of breath, ✓
*   pleuritic chest pain, ✓
*   low-grade fever and night sweats ✓



## Radiographic
*   cavities and infiltrates in upper lobes (Thin-walled cavities with lesser parenchymal infiltrates is a suggestive feature)??
*   HRCT: clusters of small nodules associated with areas of bronchiectasis in the lower and middle zones are common.
*   Asymptomatic solitary nodules noted due to MAC (Cavity nodules Bx)



## Microbiologic (important: Species identification)
*   AFB staining ✓
*   Culture → Gold std ✓
*   Gene sequencing ✓
*   Molecular based PCR ✓
*   Mass spectrometry (MALDI TOF)based methods ✓
*   HPLC ✓

# BIOCHEMICAL TESTS : Can overlap with various species

| TEST | M. tb | NTM |
|---|---|---|
| **Niacin accumulation test** | • ++ | |
| • All species of *Mycobacterium* produce niacin (nicotinic acid) *Mycobacterium tuberculosis* accumulates the most. | | |
| **Nitrate reduction** | • ++ | ◻ |
| • Aryl sulphatase | | • ++ |
| • Amidase | | • ++ (nyl) |
| • Thermo stable catalase test | | • ++ (hemo) |

**The Tween 80 Hydrolysis test is used for differentiation of pathogenic species of scotochromogens, photochromogens and non-chromogens from the non-pathogenic members of these groups.**

# Species Identification of NTM by MALDI-TOF

*   The MALDI Biotyper System identifies microorganisms using MALDI-TOF (Matrix- Assisted Laser Desorption / Ionization Time of Flight) mass spectrometry.
*   To determine a unique proteomic fingerprint of an organism.
*   Specifically, the MALDI Biotyper System measures highly abundant proteins that are found in all microorganisms.
*   The MBT Mycobacteria Library cover 178 of the currently known 201 species and, with 807 strains, the natural variability of Mycobacteria species.

(Image of MALDI-TOF machine)

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR)-restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis (HSP65)

*   The target genes include 16S rRNA, hsp65, rpoB, and the 16S–23S internal transcribed spacer (ITS)
*   The hsp65 and rpoB genes and ITS are more discriminative
